titleStmt.title:
An Appology to the Rt 08─ Honbl 08 08── ye
Lady Carteret in Ierland
by \Delany·over erasure\
\D.D.F.T.C.D.·presumably added with the other insertions about Delany\

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Lady Carteret invited \del·Dean Swift·add·Doctor Delany\ to Dinner when he come, \add·She\ not being at home the \del·Dean·add·Doctor\ went away. At my Ladys return, She enquired for him & hearing what had past, Sent the next day to invite him, when he came he went to make an Appology for his going away but my Lady told him she would have none but in verse.
A Lady wise as well as fair
Whose Conscience always was her care
Thoughtfull upon a point of Moment
Would know the Text as well \add·as\ Comment
Hearing of a grave Devine
She Sent to bid him come and dine
But you must know he was not quite
So grave, as to be Unpolite
Thought humane Learning would not lessen
The dignity of his profession
And if you heard the man discourse
Or preach, you'de like him ne're the worse
He long had bid the Court fare-well
Retreating to his Silent Cell
Suspected for the Love he bore
To one \add·who\ Sway'd Some time before
Which made it more surprizing how
He Should be Sent for thither now
The Message told, he gapes and Stares
And Scarce beleives his Eyes or Ears
Could not conceive what it Should mean
And fain would have it told again
But then th' Esquire's so trime & nice
T'was rude to make him tell it twice
So bow'd was thankfull for the honour
And would not fail to wait upon her
His beaver brush'd his Shoes and Gown
Away he trudges into town
Passes the Castle-Tower yard
And now advancing thro' the Guard
He trembles at the thought of State
For conscious of \add·his\ Sheepish Gate
His Spirits of a Sudden fail'd him
He Stopt, and could not tell \add·what\ ail'd him
“What was ye Message I receiv'd?
“Why certainly the Captain rav'd
“To dine wth── her and come at three
“Impossible it cou'd not be
“It may be I mistook the Word
“My Lady──── It must be my Lord
“My Lord's Abroad my Lady too
“What must th'── unhappy Dr─ do?
“Is Capt─ Cruchrode here pray── no
“Nay then 'tis time for me to go
“Am I awake, or do I dream
“I'm Sure he call'd me by my name
“Nam'd me as plain, as he cou'd Speak
“And yet there must be Some Mistake
“Why what a Iest Shou'd I have been
“Now had my Lady been within
“What could I've Said? I'm mighty glad
“She went abroad── She'd thought me mad
“The hour of dining now is past
“Well then, I'll e'en go home and fast
“And Since I've scap'd being made a Scoff
“I think I'm very fairly off
My Lady now returning home
Call'd──── Crutchrode, is the Dr Come?
He had not heard of him, pray See
'Tis now \second·now·canceled\ a quarter after three
The Capt─ Walks about and Searches
Thrô all the Rooms, and Courts, & Arches
Examining all the Servants round
In vain no Doctors to be found
My Lady could not chuse but wonder
“Capt─ I fear you've made a blunder
“But \add·pray\ to morrow go at ten
“I'll try his manners once again
“If rudeness is th' essert of Knowledge
“My Son Shall never See a Colledge
The Capt─ was a man of Reading
And much good Sence as well as Breeding
Who loath to blame or to incense
Said little in his own defence
Next day another Message brought
The Dr─ frighted at his fault
Is drest, and Stealing thro' the Crowd
Now pale as death, & blush'd & bow'd
Panting and fault'ring humm'd & haw'd
Her Ladyship was gone abroad
The Capt─ too, He did not know──
Whether he Ought to Stay or go
Beg'd She'd forgive him── in conclusion
My Lady pity'd his Confusion
Call'd her good Nature to releive him
Told him She thought She might beleive him
And would not only grant his Suit
But visit him & eat Some fruit
Provided at a proper time
He told the real truth in Rhyme
T'was to no purpose to Oppose
She'de hear of no Excuse in Prose
The Docr─ Stood not to debate
Glad to compound at any rate
So bowing Seemingly complyed
Tho' if \add·he\ durst he had deny'd
But first resolv'd to Show his taste
Was too refin'd to make a feast
He'de treat wth── Nothing that \add·was\, rare
But Winding walks, & purer Air
He'd entertain Without expence
Or pride, or vain Magnificence
For well he knew for Such \add·a\ Guest
The plainest Meat must be the best
To Stomachs Cloy'd With Costly Fare
Simplicity alone is rare
Whilst high & nice & curious meats
Are really but Vulgar Treats
Instead of Spoils of Persian Looms
The Costly boasts of regal Rooms
Thought it more courtly & discreet
To Scetter Roses at her feet
Roses of richest Dye that Shone
With Native Lustre like her own
Beauty that Needs no air of art
Thrô ev'ry Sense to reach the heart
The gracious Dame Althô She knew
All this was much beneath her Due
Lik'd ev'ry thing at Least thought fit
To praise it par Maniere d'aquit
But yet tho' seeming pleasd can't bear,
The scorching Sun or chilling Air,
Fright'd alike at both Extreams,
If he display or hides his Beams.
Tho seemingly pleas'd at all She Sees,
Starts at ye─ rustling of the trees
Can scarcely speak is out of Breath
In half a Walk fatigu'd to Death
The Doctor takes his Hints fm─ hence
To vindicate his late Offence
Mad:m the mighty Power of Use
Now strongly pleads in my Excuse
If You unus'd have scarcely Strength
To move \add·this\ Walks untoward Length.
If startl'd at a Scene so rude,
Thrô long Disuse of Solitude
If long confin'd to Fires & Screens
You Dread the Waving of these Greens
If Trees that neither see nor hear
Nor speak nor walk can give you fear
If You who long have breath'd the Fumes
Of City Fogs & crowded Rooms
Do now sollicitously shun
The cooler Air & dazling Sun
If Sol's Majestick Eye you flee
Learn hence── t'excuse & pity Me
Consider what it is to bear
The powder'd Courtier's witty Snear
To see the important Man of Dress
Snouching my Colledge Awkardness
To be \add·ye─\ Strutting Cornet's Sport
To run the Gauntlet of ye─ Court
Winding my Way by slow Approaches
Thro' Crowds of Coxcombs & of Coaches
From the first Fierce cockaded Sentry,
Quite thro' the Tribe of Waiting Gentry.
To pass so many crowded Stages
And stand ye─ staring of ye─ pages
And after All to crown my Spleen
Be told you are── not to be seen
Of if you are── be forc'd to bear,
The Awe of yr─ Majestick Air
And can I then be faulty found,
In dreading this Vexatious round
Can it be strange if I eschew
A Sence so Glorious & so New?
Or \add·is\ He criminal that flies,
The living Lustre of yr Eyes?
